description:
Plasmodium brasilianum is a species of malaria parasite that primarily infects non-human primates, particularly New World monkeys, in South America. It is a protozoan parasite that belongs to the genus Plasmodium, which includes the parasites that cause malaria in humans and other vertebrates.

The life cycle of Plasmodium brasilianum is similar to that of other Plasmodium species, involving both sexual and asexual stages. The parasite is transmitted by the bites of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes, which serve as the vector. Once inside the host, the parasites undergo a series of developmental stages, including the invasion of liver cells (hepatocytes) and the subsequent release of merozoites, which then infect red blood cells (erythrocytes).

Within the red blood cells, the parasites undergo further asexual replication, leading to the characteristic cycles of fever and other clinical symptoms associated with malaria. Some parasites also develop into sexual forms, called gametocytes, which can be taken up by feeding mosquitoes, completing the parasite's life cycle.

Plasmodium brasilianum is primarily found in areas of South America, particularly in the Amazon basin, where it co-exists with its non-human primate hosts. The study of this species has provided valuable insights into the evolutionary relationships and host-parasite interactions within the Plasmodium genus, as well as the potential for zoonotic transmission of malaria-like diseases between non-human primates and humans.
